elements.content: A novel chiral coordination polymer with a bikitaite zeolite framework has been constructed based on asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks, in which the original chiralities derive from the configurational effect of benzotriazole ligands and transfer to the whole network through four distinct single helical chains.
elements.clean_text: A novel chiral coordination polymer with a bikitaite zeolite framework has been constructed based on asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks, in which the original chiralities derive from the configurational effect of benzotriazole ligands and transfer to the whole network through four distinct single helical chains.

elements.content: An unprecedented chiral metal−organic framework with a bikitaite zeolite network has been constructed based on asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks, in which the original chiralities derive from the configurational effect of benzotriazole ligands and transfer to the whole chiral network through four distinct single helical chains.
elements.clean_text: An unprecedented chiral metal-organic framework with a bikitaite zeolite network has been constructed based on asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks, in which the original chiralities derive from the configurational effect of benzotriazole ligands and transfer to the whole chiral network through four distinct single helical chains.

elements.content: Inorganic zeolites have been extensively studied as microporous materials due to their widespread applications in adsorption, ion exchange, and heterogeneous catalysis. Recently, design and construction of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) with zeolite topologies have also received considerable attention for their intriguing varieties of architecture and their potential applications as functional materials. An effective and successful synthetic strategy in this field is constructing tetrahedral building blocks with four connections by the rational design of the organic ligands and properly selecting metal ions. Recently, some research on imidazolate and its derivatives has been reported in which serial novel zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) such as BCT (Mg-BCTT), ANA (analcime), and GIS (gismondine), etc. have been successfully assembled by constructing tetrahedral building blocks as the four connections, where deprotoned imidazole (IM) can form an M−IM−M angle close to 145° (M = Zn, Co), which is coincident with the Si−O−Si angle typically found in traditional zeolites. However, as the natural choice for porous materials, the topologies of zeolite in MOFs are still a tiny part among all of the zeolizic structures explored.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Inorganic zeolites have been extensively studied as microporous materials due to their widespread applications in adsorption, ion exchange, and heterogeneous catalysis. Recently, design and construction of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with zeolite topologies have also received considerable attention for their intriguing varieties of architecture and their potential applications as functional materials. An effective and successful synthetic strategy in this field is constructing tetrahedral building blocks with four connections by the rational design of the organic ligands and properly selecting metal ions. Recently, some research on imidazolate and its derivatives has been reported in which serial novel zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) such as BCT (Mg-BCTT), ANA (analcime), and GIS (gismondine), etc. have been successfully assembled by constructing tetrahedral building blocks as the four connections, where deprotoned imidazole (IM) can form an M-IM-M angle close to 145° (M = Zn, Co), which is coincident with the Si-O-Si angle typically found in traditional zeolites. However, as the natural choice for porous materials, the topologies of zeolite in MOFs are still a tiny part among all of the zeolizic structures explored.

elements.content: Meanwhile, the construction of chiral microporous materials has aroused a great deal of attention because of their utility in heterogeneous catalysis, enantioselective separations, and so on. Abundant chiral MOFs have been synthesized by using chiral organic ligands, chiral metal complexes, or spontaneous resolution from achiral materials without any chiral auxiliaries. Among all four-connected frameworks, only a handful of chiral structures have been reported, which include the chiral polymorph of zeolite β(BEA) and pure enantiomer diamond net compound based on d-camphoric acid. For inorganic zeolites or zeolite MOFs, in view of the fact that they are derived from the high symmetry of their skeletons and the achiral basic tetrahedral building blocks, such as [SiO4]4− and [AlO4]5− or MT4 (M = center metal atom and T = organic ligand), the generation of chiral in these materials presents a difficult goal. Thus, the preparation of chiral zeolite frameworks is one of most challenging issues in synthetic chemistry and material science.
elements.clean_text: Meanwhile, the construction of chiral microporous materials has aroused a great deal of attention because of their utility in heterogeneous catalysis, enantioselective separations, and so on. Abundant chiral MOFs have been synthesized by using chiral organic ligands, chiral metal complexes, or spontaneous resolution from achiral materials without any chiral auxiliaries. Among all four-connected frameworks, only a handful of chiral structures have been reported, which include the chiral polymorph of zeolite β(BEA) and pure enantiomer diamond net compound based on d-camphoric acid. For inorganic zeolites or zeolite MOFs, in view of the fact that they are derived from the high symmetry of their skeletons and the achiral basic tetrahedral building blocks, such as [SiO4]4- and [AlO4]5- or MT4 (M = center metal atom and T = organic ligand), the generation of chiral in these materials presents a difficult goal. Thus, the preparation of chiral zeolite frameworks is one of most challenging issues in synthetic chemistry and material science.

elements.content: In contrast to the tetrahedral configuration of four different substitutes is the source of chirality in innumerable cases of organic compounds; a tetrahedrally coordinated Mabcd center with four monodentate liangds is rare in coordination chemistry. It is noteworthy that Xiong et al. have reported the compound [(CN4−C6H5)2Zn], in which the different direction of the phenyl groups around each Zn center results in the formation of three different Zn centers. Furthermore, three different zinc atoms are linked by 5-phenyl tetrazolato ligands to the noncentrosymmetric diamond network. As mentioned above, the particular sample gives us a significative inspiration: asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks including chiral information may be constructed with the presence of multi-independent four-connected metal centers and the conformational or configurational effect of organic ligands, and then, the construction of chiral zeolite MOFs can be realized based on asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks.
elements.clean_text: In contrast to the tetrahedral configuration of four different substitutes is the source of chirality in innumerable cases of organic compounds; a tetrahedrally coordinated Mabcd center with four monodentate liangds is rare in coordination chemistry. It is noteworthy that Xiong et al. have reported the compound [(CN4-C6H5)2Zn], in which the different direction of the phenyl groups around each Zn center results in the formation of three different Zn centers. Furthermore, three different zinc atoms are linked by 5-phenyl tetrazolato ligands to the noncentrosymmetric diamond network. As mentioned above, the particular sample gives us a significative inspiration: asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks including chiral information may be constructed with the presence of multi-independent four-connected metal centers and the conformational or configurational effect of organic ligands, and then, the construction of chiral zeolite MOFs can be realized based on asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks.

elements.content: Taking these points into account, we tried to synthesize chiral zeolite MOFs with zinc acetate and benzotriazole (HBTA= benzotriazole). However, compounds Zn2(1,3-μ-BTA)4 and Zn (1,2-μ-BTA)2 were usually obtained in wild hydrothermal conditions. It is worth noting that there were two crystallographically independent zinc atoms in compound Zn2(1,3-μ-BTA)4. We then selected Zn2(1,3-μ-BTA)4 as a precursor and added proportional zinc acetate and HBTA ligands to introduce other zinc atom centers. Fortunately, compound [Zn(BTA)2] (1) was successfully isolated under hydrothermal conditions, which is very stable in air, and the framework begins to decompose when heated to as high as 420 °C (Figure S3, ). To the best of our knowledge, compound 1 represents the first example of chiral MOF with a bikitaite (BIK) zeolitic topology.
elements.clean_text: Taking these points into account, we tried to synthesize chiral zeolite MOFs with zinc acetate and benzotriazole (HBTA= benzotriazole). However, compounds Zn2(1,3-μ-BTA)4 and Zn (1,2-μ-BTA)2 were usually obtained in wild hydrothermal conditions. It is worth noting that there were two crystallographically independent zinc atoms in compound Zn2(1,3-μ-BTA)4. We then selected Zn2(1,3-μ-BTA)4 as a precursor and added proportional zinc acetate and HBTA ligands to introduce other zinc atom centers. Fortunately, compound [Zn(BTA)2] (1) was successfully isolated under hydrothermal conditions, which is very stable in air, and the framework begins to decompose when heated to as high as 420 °C (Figure S3, ). To the best of our knowledge, compound 1 represents the first example of chiral MOF with a bikitaite (BIK) zeolitic topology.

elements.content: All chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin−Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000−400 cm−1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. Solid-state fluorescence spectra were measured on a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorometer (Varian) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin−Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from room temperature to 800 °C under nitrogen.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. Solid-state fluorescence spectra were measured on a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorometer (Varian) equipped with a xenon lamp and quartz carrier at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from room temperature to 800 °C under nitrogen.

elements.content: A mixture of the Zn2(1,3-μ-BTA)4 (0.603 g, 1 mmol), Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.219 g, 1 mmol), HBTA (0.595 g, 5 mmol), and H2O (14 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 180 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1. Colorless block crystals of 1 were collected and washed with distilled water and dried in air to give the product; yield, 40.6% (based on Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O). Elemental analyses calcd for C36H24N18Zn3 (904.92): C, 47.78; H, 2.67; N, 27.86. Found: C, 47.75; H, 2.69; N, 27.87. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3057 (m), 1652 (w), 1549 (m), 1452 (m), 1272 (s), 1165 (s), 999 (s), 743 (s).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Zn(BTA)2] (1)

A mixture of the Zn2(1,3-μ-BTA)4 (0.603 g, 1 mmol), Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.219 g, 1 mmol), HBTA (0.595 g, 5 mmol), and H2O (14 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 180 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. Colorless block crystals of 1 were collected and washed with distilled water and dried in air to give the product; yield, 40.6% (based on Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O). Elemental analyses calcd for C36H24N18Zn3 (904.92): C, 47.78; H, 2.67; N, 27.86. Found: C, 47.75; H, 2.69; N, 27.87. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3057 (m), 1652 (w), 1549 (m), 1452 (m), 1272 (s), 1165 (s), 999 (s), 743 (s).

elements.content: Data collection of the compound was performed on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. All absorption corrections were performed by using the SADABS program. The crystal structure was solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares (SHELXTL-97) with atomic coordinates and anisotropic thermal parameters for all nonhydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms of aromatic rings were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions by using a riding model. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in Table . CCDC 659561 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography Study

Data collection of the compound was performed on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. All absorption corrections were performed by using the SADABS program. The crystal structure was solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares (SHELXTL-97) with atomic coordinates and anisotropic thermal parameters for all nonhydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms of aromatic rings were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions by using a riding model. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in Table . CCDC 659561 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

Crystal Data and Structure Refinements for Compound <bold>1</bold> formula C36H24N18Zn3 fw 904.84 T (K) 293(2) crystal system monoclinic space group P21 a (Å) 14.1071(12) b (Å) 9.5108(8) c (Å) 15.4049(13) β (°) 113.8020(10) V (Å3) 1891.1(3) Z 2 ρcalcd (g cm−3) 1.589 M (mm−1) 1.942 F(000) 912 size (mm3) 0.17 × 0.14 × 0.11 θ (#xbo) 1.44−28.36 reflections 11745/6931 T max/T mix 0.811 and 0.731 data/restraints/params 6931/1/514 S 0.960 R 1 0.0341 wR 2 0.0653 Flack param 0.04(4) Δρmax/Δρmix (e A−3) 0.350 and −0.291

wR 2 = |∑w(|F o|2 − |F c |2)|/∑|w(F o 2)2|1/2.

Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that the compound 1 consists of three crystallographically independent zinc atoms and six BTA ligands (Figure ). Similar to the report of compound (CN4−C6H5)2Zn, the different directions of the BTA ligands around each Zn center result in the formation of three different Zn centers. Each of three Zn atoms exhibits the similar coordination mode and is located at the center of a distorted tetrahedral geometry, which is surrounded by four N atoms from BTA ligands [Zn−N, 1.980(3)−2.022(3) Å, and N−Zn−N, 99.91(13)−121.16(13)]. As compared to the previous reports from zinc atoms and BTA ligands, in compound 1, each bidentate bridging BTA ligand (1,3-μ) binding with two Zn atoms is the same as that reported in compound Zn2(1,3-μ-BTA)4. Corresponding to the presence of three zinc centers, compound 1 crystallizes in lower space group of P21. Moreover, the BTA bridge (1,3-μ) has a similar coordinate geometry to IM. Thus, when the tetrahedrally coordinated zinc atom is treated as a four-connected node and the BTA organic ligand as a linker, a three-dimensional (3D) framework of complex 1 is rationalized to be a BIK zeolitic topology whose Schläfli symbol is (54.6.8)2(5.65) (Figure ). In contrast to 5−1 units of the classical BIK structure, the secondary building units (SBUs) of compound 1 are built up of three zigzag chains running parallel to the [010] direction. The coexistent tubular building units are built from six zigzag chains in the [010] direction, which are consistent with the eight ring-opening channels in the BIK network. The SBUs and the tubular building units share common zigzag chains, resulting in the formation of the 3D BIK zeolite network.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that the compound 1 consists of three crystallographically independent zinc atoms and six BTA ligands (Figure ). Similar to the report of compound (CN4-C6H5)2Zn, the different directions of the BTA ligands around each Zn center result in the formation of three different Zn centers. Each of three Zn atoms exhibits the similar coordination mode and is located at the center of a distorted tetrahedral geometry, which is surrounded by four N atoms from BTA ligands [Zn-N, 1.980(3)-2.022(3) Å, and N-Zn-N, 99.91(13)-121.16(13)]. As compared to the previous reports from zinc atoms and BTA ligands, in compound 1, each bidentate bridging BTA ligand (1,3-μ) binding with two Zn atoms is the same as that reported in compound Zn2(1,3-μ-BTA)4. Corresponding to the presence of three zinc centers, compound 1 crystallizes in lower space group of P21. Moreover, the BTA bridge (1,3-μ) has a similar coordinate geometry to IM. Thus, when the tetrahedrally coordinated zinc atom is treated as a four-connected node and the BTA organic ligand as a linker, a three-dimensional (3D) framework of complex 1 is rationalized to be a BIK zeolitic topology whose Schläfli symbol is (54.6.8)2(5.65) (Figure ). In contrast to 5-1 units of the classical BIK structure, the secondary building units (SBUs) of compound 1 are built up of three zigzag chains running parallel to the [010] direction. The coexistent tubular building units are built from six zigzag chains in the [010] direction, which are consistent with the eight ring-opening channels in the BIK network. The SBUs and the tubular building units share common zigzag chains, resulting in the formation of the 3D BIK zeolite network.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the space group P21, and a racemic mixture has been obtained by spontaneous resolution. Here, we focus on the generation of the original chirality in this compound and the transfer of the chiral information in the whole chiral zeolite framework. In compound 1, three crystallographically independent zinc atoms have similar coordinate modes. Herein, as a representative example, the Zn1 atom is selected to analyze the particular structure. As shown in Figure S1 of the , the Zn1 atom links to Zn2, Zn3, and two Zn1 atoms through four BTA ligands, where the aromatic rings of two BTA ligands linking with the same Zn1 atoms show different directions because of the steric hindrance (the dihedral angles between the plane defined by [Zn1, Zn2, Zn3] with this two TBA rings are 78.0° and 54.4°). Thus, the four-connected Zn1 center can be treated as an asymmetrical tetrahedral building block, which links with four different substitutes and induces the original chiral information. In the structure of 1, because of the configurational effect from the asymmetric disposition of benzotriazole ligands, three asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks are constructed based on three different zinc centers, respectively (Figure a and Figure S2a of the ).
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 crystallizes in the space group P21, and a racemic mixture has been obtained by spontaneous resolution. Here, we focus on the generation of the original chirality in this compound and the transfer of the chiral information in the whole chiral zeolite framework. In compound 1, three crystallographically independent zinc atoms have similar coordinate modes. Herein, as a representative example, the Zn1 atom is selected to analyze the particular structure. As shown in Figure S1 of the , the Zn1 atom links to Zn2, Zn3, and two Zn1 atoms through four BTA ligands, where the aromatic rings of two BTA ligands linking with the same Zn1 atoms show different directions because of the steric hindrance (the dihedral angles between the plane defined by [Zn1, Zn2, Zn3] with this two TBA rings are 78.0° and 54.4°). Thus, the four-connected Zn1 center can be treated as an asymmetrical tetrahedral building block, which links with four different substitutes and induces the original chiral information. In the structure of 1, because of the configurational effect from the asymmetric disposition of benzotriazole ligands, three asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks are constructed based on three different zinc centers, respectively (Figure a and Figure S2a of the ).

elements.content: (a) Polyhedral representation of the asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks of three different zinc centers. (b−e) Views of four kinds of helical chains: the left-handed helical −Zn1−BTA− chain, the right-handed helical −Zn2−BTA− chain, the left-handed helcial −Zn3−BTA− chain, and the fourth right-handed helix −Zn1−BTA−Zn2−BTA−Zn3−BTA−Zn3−BTA− chain, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Polyhedral representation of the asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks of three different zinc centers. (b-e) Views of four kinds of helical chains: the left-handed helical -Zn1-BTA- chain, the right-handed helical -Zn2-BTA- chain, the left-handed helcial -Zn3-BTA- chain, and the fourth right-handed helix -Zn1-BTA-Zn2-BTA-Zn3-BTA-Zn3-BTA- chain, respectively.

elements.content: Subsequently, corresponding to three zigzag chains in the SBUs of zeolite network (Figure S2b of the ), three similar single helical chains (−Znn−BTA− chain) are constructed from three kinds of different asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks linked by BTA ligands via a 2-fold screw axis along the [010] direction (Figure b−d), respectively. Simultaneously, in the tubular building unit of compound 1, the fourth single helical chain [−Zn1−BTA−Zn2−BTA−Zn3−BTA−Zn3−BTA−] is formed by three kinds of asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks (Figure e and Figure S2c of the ). It is notable that each of four single helical chains has its own handness in 1: in SBUs, two of the helices (−Zn1−TBA− and −Zn3−TBA− chains) are left-handed, while the third chain (−Zn2−TBA− chain) is right-handed; in the tubular building unit, the fourth helix is right-handed with a higher swing. All four of the helices have the same pitch of 9.5 Å along the crystallographic 21 screw axis. As compared with the early reports about helical complexes, no example of four distinct single helices with respective handness has been found in a stable crystalline solid. It is worthy pointing out that by shÅ the Zn1, Zn2, and Zn3 atoms, the four helices in the tubular building units interweave with six single helical chains (−Znn−TBA− chains) in three SBUs arranging an intriguing windstick fashion in the [001] direction (Figure ), which achieves the transfer and preservation of chiralities in the whole structure. Significantly, the windstick arrangement fashion coincides with the application of the concept of forbidden zones to the design of chiral zeolite frameworks: the eight ring-opening channels running along with 21 axis in the [010] direction can be viewed as the forbidden zone, and three different unsymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks arrange around the forbidden zone to form the fourth right-handed helical chain (Figure S2c of the ).
elements.clean_text: Subsequently, corresponding to three zigzag chains in the SBUs of zeolite network (Figure S2b of the ), three similar single helical chains (-Znn-BTA- chain) are constructed from three kinds of different asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks linked by BTA ligands via a 2-fold screw axis along the [010] direction (Figure b-d), respectively. Simultaneously, in the tubular building unit of compound 1, the fourth single helical chain [-Zn1-BTA-Zn2-BTA-Zn3-BTA-Zn3-BTA-] is formed by three kinds of asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks (Figure e and Figure S2c of the ). It is notable that each of four single helical chains has its own handness in 1: in SBUs, two of the helices (-Zn1-TBA- and -Zn3-TBA- chains) are left-handed, while the third chain (-Zn2-TBA- chain) is right-handed; in the tubular building unit, the fourth helix is right-handed with a higher swing. All four of the helices have the same pitch of 9.5 Å along the crystallographic 21 screw axis. As compared with the early reports about helical complexes, no example of four distinct single helices with respective handness has been found in a stable crystalline solid. It is worthy pointing out that by shÅ the Zn1, Zn2, and Zn3 atoms, the four helices in the tubular building units interweave with six single helical chains (-Znn-TBA- chains) in three SBUs arranging an intriguing windstick fashion in the [001] direction (Figure ), which achieves the transfer and preservation of chiralities in the whole structure. Significantly, the windstick arrangement fashion coincides with the application of the concept of forbidden zones to the design of chiral zeolite frameworks: the eight ring-opening channels running along with 21 axis in the [010] direction can be viewed as the forbidden zone, and three different unsymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks arrange around the forbidden zone to form the fourth right-handed helical chain (Figure S2c of the ).

elements.content: The experiment was performed on the sample consisting of numerous single crystals of 1 under N2 atm with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The TGA of complex 1 shows that the complex has high thermal stability (Figure S3 of the ), which has no weight loss below 420 °C but decomposes at a higher temperature than 420 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal and Photoluminescence Property

The experiment was performed on the sample consisting of numerous single crystals of 1 under N2 atm with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The TGA of complex 1 shows that the complex has high thermal stability (Figure S3 of the ), which has no weight loss below 420 °C but decomposes at a higher temperature than 420 °C.

elements.content: The photoluminescent property of compound 1 was studied at room temperature. As depicted in Figure , the spectrum displays a broad emission peak at 337 nm under excitation at 295 nm. The free HBTA is a luminescent compound with weak emissions at 350 nm. Thus, the luminescent behavior of 1 should be assigned to the π→π* charge transition within the aromatic rings of the BTA ligand. The emission maximum of 1 undergoes a slight blue shift relative to that of the ligand, which is probably because the HBTA ligand is deprotonated and the energy gap between the π* and the π molecular orbitals of BTA increases.
elements.clean_text: The photoluminescent property of compound 1 was studied at room temperature. As depicted in Figure , the spectrum displays a broad emission peak at 337 nm under excitation at 295 nm. The free HBTA is a luminescent compound with weak emissions at 350 nm. Thus, the luminescent behavior of 1 should be assigned to the π→π* charge transition within the aromatic rings of the BTA ligand. The emission maximum of 1 undergoes a slight blue shift relative to that of the ligand, which is probably because the HBTA ligand is deprotonated and the energy gap between the π* and the π molecular orbitals of BTA increases.

elements.content: In summary, the first chiral MOF with BIK zeolite topology, [Zn(BTA)2], has been successfully constructed based on the asymmetrical tetrahedral building block in which four distinct single-helical chains including different chiral informations are assembled from asymmetrical tetrahedral blocks. Three single-helical chains in the SBUs are linked by the fourth single-helical chain in a tubular building unit and further form the whole chiral BIK zeolite MOF. The preparation of compound 1 reveals a novel example for the synthesis of chiral zeolite MOFs with the asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks, which may provide a promising method for overcoming the potential difficulty of constructing chiral zeolite structures through reasonable designing and building asymmetrical tetrahedral units.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the first chiral MOF with BIK zeolite topology, [Zn(BTA)2], has been successfully constructed based on the asymmetrical tetrahedral building block in which four distinct single-helical chains including different chiral informations are assembled from asymmetrical tetrahedral blocks. Three single-helical chains in the SBUs are linked by the fourth single-helical chain in a tubular building unit and further form the whole chiral BIK zeolite MOF. The preparation of compound 1 reveals a novel example for the synthesis of chiral zeolite MOFs with the asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks, which may provide a promising method for overcoming the potential difficulty of constructing chiral zeolite structures through reasonable designing and building asymmetrical tetrahedral units.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data in CIF format, TGA data and molecular structure figures for compound 1, and experimental synthesis of Zn2(1,3-μ-BTA)4. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Zn(BTA)2] (1)

A mixture of the Zn2(1,3-μ-BTA)4 (0.603 g, 1 mmol), Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.219 g, 1 mmol), HBTA (0.595 g, 5 mmol), and H2O (14 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated at 180 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. Colorless block crystals of 1 were collected and washed with distilled water and dried in air to give the product; yield, 40.6% (based on Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O). Elemental analyses calcd for C36H24N18Zn3 (904.92): C, 47.78; H, 2.67; N, 27.86. Found: C, 47.75; H, 2.69; N, 27.87. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3057 (m), 1652 (w), 1549 (m), 1452 (m), 1272 (s), 1165 (s), 999 (s), 743 (s).


cln_elements.content: The experiment was performed on the sample consisting of numerous single crystals of 1 under N2 atm with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The TGA of complex 1 shows that the complex has high thermal stability (Figure S3 of the ), which has no weight loss below 420 °C but decomposes at a higher temperature than 420 °C.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal and Photoluminescence Property

The experiment was performed on the sample consisting of numerous single crystals of 1 under N2 atm with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The TGA of complex 1 shows that the complex has high thermal stability (Figure S3 of the ), which has no weight loss below 420 °C but decomposes at a higher temperature than 420 °C.

cln_elements.content: Coordination geometry of zinc atoms in compound 1 with thermal ellipsoids at 30% probability displacement; the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) 1 + x, y, z; (ii) 3 − x, −0.5 + y, 1 − z; (iii) 2 − x, 0.5 + y, 1 − z; and (iv) 1 − x, 0.5 + y, −z.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination geometry of zinc atoms in compound 1 with thermal ellipsoids at 30% probability displacement; the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) 1 + x, y, z; (ii) 3 - x, -0.5 + y, 1 - z; (iii) 2 - x, 0.5 + y, 1 - z; and (iv) 1 - x, 0.5 + y, -z.

cln_elements.content: Polyhedral and ball-stick diagram of the BIK zeolite net of compound 1 along the [010] direction. (a) The second building unit (SBU) with three zigzag chains. (b) The tubular building unit with six zigzag chains.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Polyhedral and ball-stick diagram of the BIK zeolite net of compound 1 along the [010] direction. (a) The second building unit (SBU) with three zigzag chains. (b) The tubular building unit with six zigzag chains.

cln_elements.content: (a) Polyhedral representation of the asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks of three different zinc centers. (b−e) Views of four kinds of helical chains: the left-handed helical −Zn1−BTA− chain, the right-handed helical −Zn2−BTA− chain, the left-handed helcial −Zn3−BTA− chain, and the fourth right-handed helix −Zn1−BTA−Zn2−BTA−Zn3−BTA−Zn3−BTA− chain, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Polyhedral representation of the asymmetrical tetrahedral building blocks of three different zinc centers. (b-e) Views of four kinds of helical chains: the left-handed helical -Zn1-BTA- chain, the right-handed helical -Zn2-BTA- chain, the left-handed helcial -Zn3-BTA- chain, and the fourth right-handed helix -Zn1-BTA-Zn2-BTA-Zn3-BTA-Zn3-BTA- chain, respectively.

cln_elements.content: (a) Polyhedral view of building of the fourth right-handed helix interweaving with six single helical −Znn−BTA− chains in the [010] and [100] direction. (b) Schematic view of the windstick fashion with seven single helices along different directions.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Polyhedral view of building of the fourth right-handed helix interweaving with six single helical -Znn-BTA- chains in the [010] and [100] direction. (b) Schematic view of the windstick fashion with seven single helices along different directions.

metadata.title:
Assembly of a Chiral Bikitaite Zeolite Metal−Organic Framework Based on the Asymmetrical Tetrahedral Building Blocks
Chiral BIK Zeolite Metal−Organic Framework
